prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Field and array configurations: We propose to carry out mosaic observations of three relatively nearby OB star-forming regions NGC6334I&I(N) [d~1.26 kpc], M17 [d~1.98 kpc], G35.20-0.74 [d~2.19 kpc]. Our main goal is to constrain the star formation parameters of massive stars through a statistical approach. In the case NGC6334I&I(N), we plan to cover an area of ~ 3.5' x 5.6'in 84 pointings.
Angular resolution: We want to resolve 0.1 pc (~ 20000 AU at 2.2 kpc distance) filamentary structures. At the most distant cloud in our target selection, this gives about 9 arcsec. In order to properly resolve the structures, we have requested 2 arcsec beam size (~ 1/5) of the size of the structures we want to resolve. Fortunately, we can still be able to recover 8 arcsec structures.
Sensitivity: Using N2H+ line (peak brightness temperature ~ 30 K), which we will like to detect at 10 sigma (3 K corresponding to 80.68 mJy).
Velocity resolution: To robustly disentagle the different velocity components in the filamentary structures, and the resolve velocity structures in detected cores, we have opted for 0.2 km/s resolution.
Correlator Setup and spectral lines: Since our focus is on the colder dense filamentary structures around luminous massive protostars, our spectral setup primarily includes the lowest excitation transitions of dense gas tracers: N2H+ (1-0) and HNC (1-0). Recent ALMA observations have shown the benefit of using N2H+ (1-0) to detect the dense gas counterparts to the mid-infrared dark filamentary structures. In addition we have included the higher excitation lines of CH3OH (13-12) and CH3CN J=5-4 to trace the warmer and denser protostellar gas. SO2 (3-2) will serve as an ideal shock tracer.
Integration time:
The project with further demonstrate ALMA capability to achieve impressive science goal with minimal observation time. Our total onsource time is 14 minutes, while the calibrations and overhead with take 30.7 minutes, so this science goal with be completed in ~ 45 minutes of observation.
Data rate: The data rate of this project is 1.4 times the suggested 12 MB/s limit. This is required for covering the proposed lines, and to allow robustly picking the line-free channels.

Field and array configurations: We plan to do a 95-pointing mosaic covering ~4' x 6' area in M17.
Angular resolution: We want to resolve 0.1 pc (~ 20000 AU at 2.2 kpc distance) filamentary structures. At the most distant cloud in our target selection, this gives about 9 arcsec. In order to properly resolve the structures, we have requested 2 arcsec beam size (~ 1/5) of the size of the structures we want to resolve. Fortunately, we can still be able to recover 8 arcsec structures.
Sensitivity: The weakest line can be detected at peak brightness temperature ~ 20 K, which we will like to detect at 10 sigma (2 K corresponding to 53.78 mJy).
Velocity resolution: To robustly disentagle the different velocity components in the filamentary structures, and the resolve velocity structures in detected cores, we have opted for 0.2 km/s resolution.
Correlator Setup and spectral lines: Since our focus is on the colder dense filamentary structures around luminous massive protostars, our spectral setup primarily includes the lowest excitation transitions of dense gas tracers: N2H+ (1-0) and HNC (1-0). Recent ALMA observations have shown the benefit of using N2H+ (1-0) to detect the dense gas counterparts to the mid-infrared dark filamentary structures. In addition we have included the higher excitation lines of CH3OH (13-12) and CH3CN J=5-4 to trace the warmer and denser protostellar gas. SO2 (3-2) will serve as an ideal shock tracer.
Integration time:
The project with further demonstrate ALMA capability to achieve impressive science goal with minimal observation time. Our total onsource time is about 16 minutes, while the calibrations and overhead with take about 34 minutes, so this science goal with be completed in about 50 minutes of observation.
Data rate: The data rate of this project is 1.4 times the suggested 12 MB/s limit. This is required for covering the proposed lines, and to allow robustly picking the line-free channels.

Field and array configurations: In the G35.20-0.74 [d~2.19 kpc], we propose to cover ~ 4' x 5' area with 85 mosaic pointings.
Angular resolution: We want to resolve 0.1 pc (~ 20000 AU at 2.2 kpc distance) filamentary structures. At the most distant cloud in our target selection, this gives about 9 arcsec. In order to properly resolve the structures, we have requested 2 arcsec beam size (~ 1/5) of the size of the structures we want to resolve. Fortunately, we can still be able to recover 8 arcsec structures.
Sensitivity: Based on Sanchez-Monge et al, (2013), we estimated the expected CH3CN line peak intensity to be about 600 mJy/beam, we want a sensitivity of 50 mJy, which will afford us an SNR of 12. This will help us go deeper and detect more cores and structures.
Velocity resolution: To robustly disentagle the different velocity components in the filamentary structures, and the resolve velocity structures in detected cores, we have opted for 0.2 km/s resolution.
Correlator Setup and spectral lines: Since our focus is on the colder dense filamentary structures around luminous massive protostars, our spectral setup primarily includes the lowest excitation transitions of dense gas tracers: N2H+ (1-0) and HNC (1-0). Recent ALMA observations have shown the benefit of using N2H+ (1-0) to detect the dense gas counterparts to the mid-infrared dark filamentary structures. In addition we have included the higher excitation lines of CH3OH (13-12) and CH3CN J=5-4 to trace the warmer and denser protostellar gas. SO2 (3-2) will serve as an ideal shock tracer.
Integration time:
The project with further demonstrate ALMA capability to achieve impressive science goal with minimal observation time. Our total onsource time is ~15 minutes, while the calibrations and overhead with take 30.7 minutes, so this science goal with be completed in ~ 46 minutes of observation.
Data rate: The data rate of this project is 1.4 times the suggested 12 MB/s limit. This is required for covering the proposed lines, and to allow robustly picking the line-free channels.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: With currently existing sample of massive star-forming (MSF) regions with known parallax distances, the time has arrived for us harness improved accuracy and take high-mass star studies to a higher precision level with ALMA. In this proposal, we aim to demostrate the feasibility of a statistical study of MSF regions in order to constrain their formation parameters with their accurate distance at our disposal. Among the parameters; typical width of filament (are they really 0.1 pc as proposed using Herschel?), core mass function (we will test the universality of core mass function), clumps virial parameter analysis will also help us test the role of competitive accretion in the formation of high-mass stars, and the possible influence of magnetic field in the formation process. We have complementary observations with Nobeyama 45m, and Mopra radio telecopes for investigating the influence of large scale structures.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: ALMA Project Office, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
